sections.heading: Program overview
paragraphs: In the Vehicle Engineering master’s program you will be exploring the design, development, production, and operation of motor vehicles and rail vehicles. Complex systems and new technologies form a particular area of focus. During the program you can choose to specialize in one of the following areas: vehicle safety, vehicle dynamics, vehicle legislation, vehicle efficiency, process management in vehicle engineering, the design and construction of motor vehicles and rail vehicles, or the human-machine interaction in vehicles.

You can choose between the fields of motor vehicles and rail vehicles when deciding on your area of specialization. The field of motor vehicles focuses on autonomous driving, chassis control systems, vehicle dynamics, vehicle safety, vehicle efficiency, and automotive development methods. The research topics addressed within the field of rail vehicles cover the entire spectrum of railroad technology, including acoustics and the safety of rail vehicles, accident reconstruction, and the utilization of energy and resources.

sections.heading: Admission requirements
paragraphs: As with every master’s degree at TU Berlin, a first university degree is a formal requirement of studying in the Vehicle Engineering master’s program. Further details can be found in the application and admission regulations/study and examination regulations for the degree program . Until legal validity of the application and admission regulations (estimated to start for the admission of winter semester 2019/20) the following rules apply.

The Vehicle Engineering master’s program is taught in German. If you are applying with a foreign school-leaving certificate, you must provide proof of German skills at a specific level. This is a prerequisite for admission. Knowledge of English is useful, as some courses/modules may be offered in English and much of the technical literature is published in English. However, it is not a condition for admission to studies.

The international character of engineering as well as its economic, legal and political dimensions mean that communication and team skills are of fundamental importance in this branch of industry. An interest in, and aptitude for these skills are therefore advantageous.

sections.heading: Program structure
paragraphs: There is a proposed course schedule for the degree program. This is a recommendation for how to complete the degree program within the standard period of study of four semesters. It provides an example of which modules to take in which semesters. While this proposed course schedule is ideal on paper, it is not mandatory. It’s simply an example of how to successfully schedule and shape your studies.

You can find the proposed course schedule in the study and examination regulations. The latest version applies to applicants. The latest version of these regulations always applies to applicants. The module list in the appendix to the StuPO is constantly updated, but cannot be changed here. The current and binding module list can be found in the online module directory .
We recommend you start your studies in the winter semester, as beginning in the summer semester requires special planning.

sections.heading: Content and modules
paragraphs: The Vehicle Engineering master’s program is made up of modules which group the content of the curriculum into specific topics and which often include various forms of study and teaching. A current overview of all modules is available in TU Berlin’s module transfer system (MTS). This database of modules provides an overview of which modules are compulsory and which are elective. Detailed module descriptions provide information on the content, learning outcomes, participation requirements, the workload, assessment methods, and much more. The module list is based on the study and examination regulations. The latest version applies to applicants.

sections.heading: Internships
paragraphs: A six-week non-university, technical internship is compulsory for this master’s program. The internship should focus on overseeing an entire project or offer the opportunity to participate in a project. All further details can be found in the regulations governing internships.

sections.heading: Stays abroad
paragraphs: Generally, parts of the program can be completed abroad, either as semesters abroad or internships. General information concerning stays abroad is available from the TU Berlin International Office (studying abroad) or the Career Service (internships abroad).

sections.heading: Acquired skills
paragraphs: The master’s program enables you to take up a managerial position in industry or business. The program equips you with both the fundamental principles of vehicles in a broader context and specialist knowledge of vehicle safety, vehicle dynamics, vehicle legislation, vehicle efficiency, process management and vehicle engineering, the design and construction of motor vehicles and rail vehicles, and the human-machine interaction in vehicles. This provides you with a thorough understanding of technological processes and the interrelationships of the different fields, essential for the independent solving of complex problems. Through the program’s focus on projects designed to reflect issues in the automotive industry, you also acquire highly developed systems skills.

sections.heading: After your studies
paragraphs: Our graduates enjoy excellent career prospects. Examples of the areas in which you can work include the design, development, and production of motor vehicles or rail vehicles as well as their components (working both within the automotive industry and for its suppliers) and research into the safety of vehicles in public spaces, technical operation or management, working for vehicle manufacturers. You can also work for monitoring organizations and public authorities, or as an assessor or technical expert.
Obtaining a master’s also qualifies you for a doctorate and the opportunity to pursue an academic career.
